title: Appointments
body:
It is ridiculously limiting and frustrating to try and get an appointment - even when requested to contact the surgery to discuss results.
You have a limited window of 8:30am - 8:31am Thursday morning to try and obtain an appointment...miss the small window of opportunity and you have to ring back the week after because all the appointments have gone (even if you manage to get through the appointment will be weeks away!). 
So tried on-line as I am registered for online services to be presented with the message - Sorry, your practice does not currently have any appointment slots that can be booked online! ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
What's the point of an on-line service you cannot utilise? Even if the appointment will be weeks in advance (as it will be even if you call in) at least allow it to be booked rather than having to go through the telephone lottery on Thursday morning to be told it will be weeks in advance and take up receptionist time.

Can you imagine utilising your supermarkets app they encourage you to use to save time to do your online shopping to then be told there is no food available! 

Seriously can things get any worse in the NHS service (probably!). it is a total mess and any other business run in this manner would have closed down a long time ago. 

The management of the NHS is a mess and needs a total overhaul - this is not a reflection of the workers who have to work with the broken system.

title: Only one part time doctor on Payroll
body: The surgery has only one part time doctor on payroll at this practice. They are relying on part time locums to deal with patients. I understand that admin staff are leaving the practice as well, one at least who had been there many years. The admin staff are working as hard as they can but can't do much if there aren't any doctors in the practice. Test results aren't being looked at promptly, patients not being contacted to discuss results, waiting times to see anyone are horrendous, although they seem to do most contacts by telephone. I understand that this is because they haven't got any doctors but it means that patients in effect don't have a real service

author: Nb61mum
title: Antenatal clinic / unplanned c-section / aftercare.
body:
I would like to share some of positive and negative feedback regarding our experience. Firstly we would love to thank Jennifer, our midwife in labour ward, who supported us through a stressful and complicated birth resulting in an unplanned c-section, and her aftercare while in recovery was above and beyond.  
Also to the theatre staff, in particular Roxy who performed the procedure and Kevin the anaesthetist who made me feel so safe in labour ward and theatre (I was terrified of having any form of medication given that I had previous drug allergies, but felt Kevin who took the time to listen to my concerns and explained and reassured myself and partner throughout the process.  
However we had a really unpleasant experience with the antenatal clinic. Having had a straightforward pregnancy and being on the green pathway right through and also planning for community midwife led birth, I found it deeply frustrating having to attend the antenatal clinic at Aberdeen Maternity Hospital (AMH). The doctor we were seen by at the clinic on our last visit failed to introduce themselves so we have no idea who they are. Both my partner and I felt our opinions and wishes were completely ignored during this appointment. Their approach was very impersonal and felt like we were being forced to book interventions that weren‚Äôt discussed or explained at all and there was no informed consent. After eventually telling us they were going to get a leaflet, they returned with the consultant without informing us this was happening. Our experience in clinic ruined the end of what had been a perfect and happy pregnancy.  
We also feel let down by the level of aftercare from Inverurie Community Maternity Unit (CMU) following the birth of our first baby. Having had complications with my own health after birth, and it being in writing on hospital discharge letter for the community midwife to re-check my blood pressure prior to discharge and to refer to GP for ongoing treatment. This never happened. Which resulted in me having no medication for 2 weeks, and ultimately calling nhs24 and a re-admission to triage for treatment. A hospital admission which likely could have been avoided had appropriate follow up care and prescription been in place. Also, failure to provide adequate information to our health visitor team regarding a 13% weight loss of our baby and re-admission for feeding support, which would be important for them to understand in regards to her development.  
Our health visitor services have been brilliant and provided so much more support in relation to feeding and continue to provide excellent care. Anne in particular has been so helpful in the early days following the arrival of our first baby and we are very grateful for her support and communication.

readBy.name: Aberdeen City Health & Social Care Partnership

links.id: willingness to listen to parents opinions
making sure all health visitors give the same care

author: librakh83
title: Our trust in healthcare professionals is now strained.
body:
We had to take our daughter t the paediatric assessment unit in Aberdeen children‚Äôs hospital at night, due to having 20+ clusters of seizures in that day; that are worsening & progressive. She was already assessed for having 12-14 seizure episodes a couple of days before this. We were promptly taken through to the ward upon arrival. Put into triage 5 room by a nurse, that had bright lights, very hot and no ventilation.  
About 5 hours later, a speciality 1 doctor came to take bloods from my daughters foot, they attempted the toe but failed and the nurse said they were using too much paraffin on her left big toe as the tube was slipping, combined with my daughter clenching her toes made it very tricky - the doctor was great with her, kept her calm and was empathetic towards her. She tolerated it much better than we all expected and said how great she was doing, however the doctor was failing to get sufficient drops of blood from the toe and moved to her heel on the opposite foot. The doctor unfortunately did the same again, using too much paraffin which made the tube slip on her foot but my daughter was still doing great, considering she had 25 episodes of seizures, in a very hot room, strange place and incredibly tired and exhausted.  
The nurse who admitted us on arrival and took my daughters' first set of observations decided to take over as my baby‚Äôs foot was bleeding and the blood test was needed (totally understandable). However this is where my babies discomfort, and ours as parents changed. The nurse used such pressure and force to get the blood from her heel that she bent her right foot back so far that her toes were in line with her shin of her lower half of her leg. My baby was absolutely distraught and screaming, in what very much so seemed like a lot of pain.  
My daughter clearly displayed better than expected behaviour when having her toe and heel cut two times by the doctor and blood drawn by them, she was curious to see what was happening and we managed a little distraction with rattles and sucrose drops, and without this awfully distressing response. Nor did they need to bend her foot back so far. Nor did we experience this when having bloods taken multiple times for blood sugars, or the heel prick test when in NICU for 6 days when first born.  
I stated to the nurse than they were hurting my daughter and they ignored me, they also ignored how distraught my daughter was. Zero empathy to an already very unpleasant situation we were in with worry about our daughter, and how she had been kept awake in horrible conditions. How she‚Äôd been taken up to hospital, for seizures with an unknown cause outside of the usual reasons with babies, and due to this I was a bit worried about putting her through more but my daughter was doing so well until it felt like this nurse brutally bent her foot back to obtain a blood sample. The nurse very clearly displayed their frustrations with the doctor who failed 2 attempts. Bloods were required because we couldn‚Äôt establish a cause, but brute force and zero empathy for a small baby was not necessary and only caused us as first time parents and my child undue distress and trauma.  
I would like this nurse to be retrained on patient ethics and empathy towards children and parents who were clearly concerned. Perhaps retraining on taking bloods from children who are curious and pleasant, as I would hate to think how a child would be treated if they put up any resistance. At no point were we even asked if someone in training could take the bloods - given these circumstances we would have probably declined to minimise the distress imposed on our child.  
I would like this to be dealt with so no other child has to endure this kind of treatment, and so that no parents have to watch their child be treated this way when not well. My daughter is still having progressive seizures, sleeping more than usual and lower appetite than usual, so it is likely we will need more investigation despite a normal ECG & EEG. So we would hope that we never have to experience this ever again because our trust in healthcare professionals is now strained.

readBy.name: Aberdeen City Health & Social Care Partnership

links.id: not using brute force with children

title: Surprised at lack of covid precautions
body:
As an immunosuppressed patient I was surprised at the lack of masks lack of ventilation to protect the immunosuppressed, having read other feedback it is clear the surgery is not taking on board advice from science and data that covid is still an issue, still a risk and is air borne, ventilation and the use of Hepa filters should be a normal ‚Äò risk assessment‚Äô made in all health care settings to mitigate the risk of covid to the most at risk, although not surprised given Vine surgeries overall lack of attention to its patients.

Maybe take a read of the NHS use of Hepa filters in healthcare settings

title: GPs and nurses are good, Reception staff are awful
body: The GP's, nurses and consultants I have seen so far are great. It's the reception staff that are completely incompetent, extremely rude and downright unprofessional. They sit back and look down on you when they answer you, that's if they can be bothered to provide you with a half decent informative answer as if they are doing you a favour. They want to know all your information and then do absolutely nothing with it, by now everyone at reception has heard your private details. Loxford really needs to train its reception staff. It's shambolic the way they treat patients.

title: Draconian and rude.
body:
As a visitor to the hospital, all was great until my daughter was moved to the anti natal ward. We drove 4 hours to see her and her little brother was allowed to see her in the birth centre for a few minutes (staff were lovely). Once on the postnatal ward though, the staff were unhelpful and uncaring and said her brother was not allowed to see her. This meant I spent visiting time in a car park with him so my husband could go in, as you can‚Äôt even swap visitors during the visiting session so I couldn‚Äôt see her or the baby. Then we had to drive back 4 hours home. My daughter wasn‚Äôt well and this added so much stress for her. I thought family contact was supposed to aid recovery? 
I should explain that her brother is Autistic and so could not understand why he was not allowed to see his sister.
He is no more an infection risk than anyone else on the ward.
This should have been a happy day but instead I have a little boy who thinks he has done something wrong and a stressed out new mum.

title: Pointless service
body: I had conjunctivitis 6 weeks ago and NHS 111 on line was excellent, got me seen and treated in an hour. The condition recurred 3 weeks later, I was advised to see a pharmacist who again advised and sold me the appropriate treatment, within minutes. The conjunctivitis came back yesterday and on the instructions of the pharmacist I called my GP, to be told that they no longer look after eyes. I was given a link to this eye care service, which I used just to be told to phone my local Specsavers branch to organise an appointment. On speaking to them and giving them my full history, I am told that they will arrange an appointment for me to be examined but cannot prescribe treatment, and will have to refer me back to my GP for that. The appointment I have been given is 6 days away! What is the point of this service if it does not give a service? I suspect that by the time I am seen the condition will have cleared up again and I will be back to square one, waiting for it to reoccur and start again. Another, NHS waste of time and resources with no outcome. In the meantime, what am I supposed to do with my infection?

title: Unsympathetic GP
body:
The reception staff are great, the GP is extremely uncaring! 
Have a chest infection tried to get an appointment the receptionist kindly arranged a call back. The GP seemed irritated and insisted it wasn‚Äôt an emergency even though I explained I was sometimes breathless. I‚Äôm now in the process of changing GP

title: Useless practice
body: Phone to get a appointment I did not know about the new system they have in place so just received text messages asking for more details about what is wrong to get a text back to say I don't need to see anyone and that I will get over it myself considering I am worried as I have pain in my throat and I have just lost my mother to cancer of the thyroid that should of been pick up in the blood test she was having think CQC sound have a look at this practice

title: Appointments Difficult
body:
The system of booking appointments is poor. Took several days to obtain a blood test let alone a GP appointment. I am sure this is now commonplace. 

Once in, cannot fault the practioner.

title: Great service
body: Quick and  straightforward process. Fantastic doctor and lovely nurse. Doctor explained everything throughly.

title: Good practice
body: My recent experience went very well. I only had to wait a few minutes before  my appointment with the Nurse, which went very smoothly. However, I do find it a shame that patients are unable to see a Doctor face to face now!

author: Prasien
title: They never bother to respond
body:
We've been trying to get them to address certain issues for over a year now, someone has tried contacting them on my behalf several times, she's either ignored or told someone will get back to her but they don't.  
They tell you to contact them via email but never bother to respond, it's no good trying to ignore issues that need to be addressed, when the GP surgery is part of what has caused them.

author: wew152
title: Trying to make an appointment
body: Trying to make an appointment for my Mum who is 88 and has sudden hip pain which means she's gone from being active to using a walker. Nobody will see her in person. They recommended A&E which we refused. We had an x-ray and of course nothing is broken, but now requesting a face-to-face examination from the GP and been given an appointment in a month. That is 2 months from the initial contact. Absolutely disgraceful, in my view. This practice used to be good, and I think it not longer is. Feels like it's been utterly ruined.

author: sigmaxy67
title: Not happy that I was given wrong information
body:
I went to lagan valley urgent care following a suspected chiropractic injury. I was concerned about fracture as I was in immense pain and was aware of complications and I already have a complex medical history and am medically vulnerable.  
After my x ray I was advised by a doctor in the waiting room that I had bruised ribs and just to rest. I asked if I could have patches for the pain, they apologised profusely because I could only have 5 days of pain management, I said I didn't mind as long as I could get at least 2 nights sleep. I wasn't shown my x ray or anything  
When I looked at the discharge letter for the GP it clearly stated clinical fracture. Had I not seen that, my carer wouldn't have known how to best look after me to ensure no further complications and to keep an eye out for symptoms of complications  
I'm not happy that I was given wrong information on my own body and how to keep it safe

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust
Ulster University, Faculty of Life and Health Sciences

author: aoiy23
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: I hope that the communication with the staff can improve a bit more
body:
The care that I've been receiving has been a bit up and down, but that's mostly because of how I've been feeling lately. Overall, the treatment has been good and it really hasn't been bad at all. The staff have been very good, but I do feel that at times they could have communicated a bit more effectively about a few small things.  
To others, it may seem like a small issue, but to me, things like being told if the consultant isn‚Äôt coming around to be due to them being busy would be nice as there are times where I haven‚Äôt been informed of this. However, I do appreciate their efforts and the care that they've been providing.  
I can't say a bad word about the food because I don't eat all that often. However, I haven't really had any complaints about it either as it's been decent enough. Overall, I'm grateful for the care that I've received, and I hope that the communication with the staff can improve a bit more.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Mat230-1
title: 29 hours in A&E
body:
I had to take my husband to A&E in the early hours of the morning due to server trigeminal neuralgia attacks. 8 hrs waiting to see the 1st Dr who was very thorough and wanted a 2nd opinion which took a further 8hr wait. 16 hrs of people watching in the waiting area. Totally shocked at what some people actually came into A&E and how after a few hours wait just get up and walk out!  
I'd like to say a big thank you to the staff for continually keeping us updated during our wait, and then a trip round to majors for an infusion to help the attacks lead to another 13 hrs wait for a bed.  
All the staff involved in my husband's care treated him with great respect and care. The amount of patients on beds in corridors was shocking and upsetting to see, but the staff worked tirelessly doing their jobs.  
Being a patients relative and not a member of staff is the hardest thing to do, but knowing just the small things you do like letting them know what's happening and offering a cup of tea makes such a big difference at such a worrying time.  
While writing this my husband is still an inpatient, but that's a completely different story!

author: Concered Patient
title: I heard them suggest that this was a waste of time
body:
Hi,  
I attended Hairmyres Breast screening as I had pain in my breast. I was seen by the nurse practitioner who was professional and thorough.  
I was sent for a mammogram.  
The lady who did my mamogram was amazing. She was professional, thorough, also gentle and kind. She made a painful experience much more bearable. I felt that she really cared about me in a very short period of time. I was then taken to have an ultrasound. I was asked to wait in the small changing room.  
This is a message to the ultrasound staff - patients in the changing room can hear what you are saying.  
I heard a staff member take a phone call.  
I heard them suggest that this was a waste of time, that an ultrasound wasn't needed, that they wished mammogram would just send people on their "merry" way.  
I have a high instance of cancer in my family and I did not feel "merry". Although the conversation was overheard, I feel the attitude does not belong in such caring environment.  
The whole conversation I heard - the attitude came across as arrogant, unprofessional and gung ho.  
I was handed a letter and asked to return to the Nurse Practitioner who advised me that my pain was muscular.  
I am very relieved that it was muscular but I feel that the experience at ultrasound let an otherwise brilliant team down.

author: Sarah87
title: Cauda equina journey
body:
Last month I was rushed in for an emergency operation on my back for Cauda equina syndrome.  
I was so scared of what was happening after my MRI scan I was then taken to the wrong ward, for the porter to be screamed at that I should not have been there - the member of staff was so angry and scary looking.  
I was then took to ward 23b to be welcomed from a set of angels nursers. They were honestly so caring and loving I want to thank everyone of them they made me feel at ease. Thanks to everyone in ward 23b who helped me during my hard time.

author: jivexg77
title: My husband's support from the Community Occupational Therapist
body:
My husband was very ill at the start of year with heart failure, so we had an Occupational therapist who came out and saw him. I must admit she was excellent, she came out to start with when he left Hospital to see how he managed to go up and down stairs because he was very weak. When he came out, my son put in a double banister, so she made sure he was okay getting up and down stairs and arranged for bathroom aids so he could use the bathroom without my assistance. Eventually she came again and took him for a wee walk, just between a few lampposts, then she came back again and did the same, maybe going a little further. Then she offered to take him out again. But I said I think we were okay at that point. She did then phone a week or so ago to see how he was getting on and how we were coping, we spoke about getting a wheelchair I was going to buy, she gave me a phone number to help get a wheelchair, and she phoned to see how I got on with that. My husband said she was absolutely fantastic.  
He came out of hospital with covid, so we both had it, so the help we got from some of the other agencies wasn‚Äôt very good, but the OT service were excellent, and as soon as he was over covid they got in touch and his OT came out to see him. I think she is now saying she is going to speak to the heart nurse about accessing physio, I think she said she could refer him for that.  
The OT taking him out for a walk helped him build his confidence, giving tips to him, which made him feel more confident, that was great. He‚Äôs only seen a heart nurse face to face once, partly because of covid when he first left hospital. So I‚Äôm a bit disappointed about that, that it is just a telephone appointment he has with the heart nurse, because I think a lot can be said about seeing someone face to face. The cardiology nurse is based at Ninewells, they phone up, and they are very nice on the phone don‚Äôt get me wrong, but it‚Äôs usually me they're speaking to as my husband sometimes gets a bit confused about he medication he‚Äôs on, and the nurse is usually phoning about medication, so they end up speaking to me, but I think it would be better to have that discussion face to face so my husband can be included. I‚Äôm sure the reason we can‚Äôt have more face to face appointments with the heart nurse is probably because of staffing issues, but it is disappointing to only have these phone call and have only seen them face to face once.

readBy.name: Perth and Kinross Health & Social Care Partnership

title: Accessible GP
body: I was able to arrange a F2F appointment within a fortnight / The appointment was on time / A way forward was agreed.

title: Worst Surgery
body: Worst surgery, made me wait for more than 40 minutes for my appointment, I had to cancel at the end and go, awful Experience

title: Great practice
body: This was my first time with Healthshare and I was very impressed with them.  It was above my expectations.

title: First impressions
body: I was contacted by this provider with a booking for a ultra sound I phoned to rearrange my appoint to a more convenient time & place on doing this I was given a new appointment but I have received a letter with the old appointment details & none on the new details so I have sent two emails asking them to confirm the first one has been cancelled & the second is still ok I have not received any reply at all disappointing why put an email address if no one is going to reply.

title: Bolton Wheelchair Service
body: A referral was made by my elderly fathers GP to the wheelchair service for an assessment of his needs. The referral was rejected by letter with no valid reason as to why. Turns out when I tried to speak to someone, they blamed the GP surgery for incorrectly filling out the form. Having seen the form, I can see it was completed correctly but some information was missing, I wonder why they couldn‚Äôt chase the GP surgery to get this corrected rather than reject the referral causing upset to both the patient and carer. Eventually I spoke to the team leader who agreed to come out and carry out an assessment, this was in line with the wheelchair service referral process as detailed on the website. The assessment was then cancelled 90 minutes before it was due to take place due to staff sickness, and no-one has bothered to make contact to re-book the appointment.

title: Great Practice
body:
Having been to the now Norwich healthshare clinic in previously Global on several occasions, I cannot praise staff and comfort of the clinic. However, I miss the personal touch of being able to ring them direct re any enquires etc. now ring a main customer call centre I find it not personal and although booking arranged I did not get confirmation letter as promised nor was I told to fast for 6 hrs prior to ultrasound which I was asked on arrival!! Luckily, I had not eaten due to stomach problems.
I preferred being able to speak to the reception team in Norwich.

title: Very good experience
body:
Appointment was at exact time of appointment and carried out with politeness,dignity&respect
Many thanks

author: Anonym
title: Premature Ovarian Insufficiency (POI) - poor service
body:
I am on a follow-up service at the Premature Ovarian Insufficiency (POI) clinic.  
Last year they sent me to do a blood test, then postponed the appointment three times, each time with 3-4 months waiting times. Once I managed to get through a telephone appointment one year later, it was pointless to look at my blood test. So, they sent me again to do a blood test, only to ghost me on the day of the appointment. There was no apology, only a letter a day later saying that it was me who didn't pick up the phone, when I was eagerly sitting by the phone, set on maximum volume, all day.  
I understand that the backlog is enormous post-covid, however even before the pandemic, I felt the service was poor: in a previous face-to-face appointment, the Dr didn't look at my medical data, had no clue who I was and why I was there, didn't know how to log onto the system online and when they finally managed (by leaving our appointment to get some help), they couldn't print my test results and asked me to take photos of their handwritten notes.

readBy.name: Chelsea and Westminster Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Gallbladder Surgery Refused
body: I saw two surgeons after a referral was made by my GP, on both occasions I was told surgery was not possible due to my weight and higher BMI, and on the second time, I was pretty much dismissed out the appointment in less than 5 minutes. Using a higher-than-normal BMI, is a rather poor excuse to not operate on someone who is in pain daily, and who is also a full-time carer for a loved one. We are talking a BMI slightly over the threshold, and someone who has successfully lost 50kg in weight on their own without NHS intervention. It would have been nice had this been recognised by the professionals within the NHS. A referral to someone else who has the confidence to do a gallbladder removal on someone obese should have been an option, i.e., a surgeon who has experienced in doing bariatric surgery at a different hospital, rather than simply dismissing it to turf patients off the waiting list.

title: Disgraceful doctors
body: Can‚Äôt get any appointments and have to wait 12 days just to get a telephone appointment even though can‚Äôt eat been being sick and swollen tummy and legs

title: Great staff
body: Some of the staff are very helpful extremely happy with general assistant the nurses are amazing. They listen to your concerns. Some of the front desk staff can be rude and not very understanding

title: Incompetent- don‚Äôt waste your time
body: The receptionists are incredibly rude and patronising. They are horrible at referrals are are always making errors and overall they make situations far more stressful. Untrustworthy practice.

title: Appointment
body: I have a mole that won't stop bleeding, it is the 10th of May and I was offered an appointment in June. Really?

title: They don‚Äôt seem to care about your wellbeing
body:
For the third time in a couple of months my appointment has been moved. Due to ‚Äúunforeseen circumstances‚Äù. 

You ask for an appointment, you can have one in a weeks time. A week later. Your appointment has been moved due to unforeseen circumstances. 
Two weeks after you requested the appointment. 

No answer on the phones and no support for mental health. 

They left me on the phone telling me my infection ‚Äúdidnt sound like an infection‚Äù & they would call me back in a week. I then ended up in hospital unwell with the infection and they still cancelled my follow up appointment. 

Its a joke of a surgery , quite honestly.

title: Superb care
body: I fractured my ankle and the care and support I received from your trust was superb and far more than I expected! From the lovely people at the minor injuries unit to the cheerful chap in the trauma clinic, I will well treated and support. I then received ongoing physiotherapy (which I hadn't expected) until I was 100% back to normal function. For a minor fracture, the care was incredible and nothing was too much trouble. I was very impressed by the caliber, friendliness, professionalism and thorough attitude of all the staff I came into contact with. Thank you very much for delivering such excellent care when going through difficult times. It has made all the difference.

author: Emma308
title: Severe pain and uncertain wait for gallbladder removal
body:
I attended my GP in December following being very ill and barely able to eat over the festive period due to suspected gallstones. I was diagnosed with multiple large gallstones by ultrasound in January 2023 and advised I would likely need surgery due to how symptomatic I was and how large my gallstones were.  
My consultation with the general surgeon at Chelsea & Westminster hospital was supposed to be in March but delayed by NHS strikes to April.  
In April I let the surgeon know I had been increasingly unwell, having intermittent fevers, losing weight as I am often vomiting or scared to eat. The consultation was very short and the consultant told me I was not yet on a surgical waiting list and needed an MRI to check I had no stones blocking my ducts first.  
The consultant told me following the MRI I would need to come back to see him before he would list me for surgery, which he said is another 12 week minimum wait. I pleaded with the consultant to add me to the surgery wait list in the meantime as I was barely able to tolerate food and on an extremely low calorie diet as a result.  
Although the consultant was medically knowledgeable, I felt he was dismissive of the impact my condition is having on my daily life as he told me to simply follow a low fat diet and to attend A&E if needed.  
I cried following my appointment as I had been so patient waiting months for this appointment and really thought I would get a definitive date for surgery or at least know I was on a waiting list but I felt still completely in the dark about timescales and powerless to do anything about my own health.  
The MRI happened 4 weeks later (during which time I remained very ill, even fainting at work), but I was only given an appointment date a whole 4 months later to discuss the MRI (end of august).  
I have since managed to get a consultation sooner (June). But I am suffering so much with daily intense pain, nausea, and vomiting that this still feels ages away. I have lost 6kgs in 6 weeks and I was not overweight to begin with. I am taking codeine and antiemetics daily and I am now vomiting on a daily basis.  
I have asked my GP for antidepressants as my mood and quality of life has been totally eroded by this and some days I actually think I am dying the pain is so bad. I can no longer commit to or enjoy social plans or holidays and I am worried I will lose my job and be put on statutory sick pay as I am having attacks at work and my performance is suffering.  
I went to A&E a few weeks ago during an attack but although the staff were lovely and efficient, they said my bloodwork was fine and told me to come back only if I have a fever or develop jaundice as they can't offer me the surgery unless I develop emergency complications. At this stage I am hoping for emergency complications so I can have some resolution to my situation.  
I have no savings to afford private surgery as it's several thousands of pounds and I am having to consider borrowing money to go abroad to have the surgery, which I resent as a taxpayer who is not able to afford such an expense.  
Online I have found out about S2 funding options to have the surgery funded in Europe but not sure if the NHS would agree this as they consider me non urgent? I have also tried to ask to change hospitals as my treatment falls outside the 18 week waiting time but been discouraged from doing this by the hospital as according to the admin they said I have "already started my care at Chelsea" and switching hospitals would reset the waiting time to zero?  
I contacted PALS and spoke to someone on the phone who said they would look into my case and call me back but nobody did.  
At this stage I actually dread waking up in the morning as it's such a struggle through the day. I feel totally in the dark about my options and likely timescales- why can't this be communicated to me as an adult whose entire life is currently on hold?  
I understand and am sympathetic to the system pressures the NHS is under but communication is key, if I at least had a timeframe I could make a decision about whether I can afford to wait.  
It would also be good if the NHS has no capacity to operate on patients if they could at least proactively transfer you to another hospital or offer to part fund private treatment elsewhere or at least advertise the S2 funding route. Instead it feels patients are discouraged from trying to navigate or reorganise their care.  
Also, the advice to attend A&E every time I have pain lasting more than half an hour (which is every day!) is more costly for the NHS in the long run than elective surgery within reasonable timeframes and adds pressure on A&E staff who either have to just send patients home with painkillers after said patient has been several hours waiting to be seen or they are forced to operate on an emergency basis for something that could have happened in a safer planned way.

readBy.name: Chelsea and Westminster Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Appointment
body: The appt was delayed, but the service as always was fantastic. Very thorough and put us all at ease. Booked appt on the same day.

title: Welcome
body:
Welcomed and put at ease no question was a nuisance . Nurse had a smile and listened 
The secretary that made the appointment was so helpful and pleasant

title: Lack of information, uncaring
body:
Worried with a back pain, GP asked for stool sample, took it in to be told that I should have brought it before 11am. They asked me to redo it. Was then called to say, oh you do not have to do it, just take it to the hospital. 
Conflicting information on the leaflet provided - clearly states: containers collected from the GP - return to GP! 

The person I talked to was only defensive, did not take responsibility for the lack of information they had around this.

title: Worst practice still going
body: Honestly the worst experience trying just book an appointment. Called immediately after 8 o'clock only for the line to appointments and general inquiries to be full (pretty sure they're not even open). Went in after work to try and arrange a telephone appointment and was told they cant be prearranged and to try the non existent number again in the morning. Terrible service, and the staff were unhelpful in actually trying to assist, just vainly apologetic. Actually going to register at another GP now - avoid at all costs

title: Through investigations despite being so busy
body: We took an elderly vulnerable friend to ED, armed with a letter from our GP, due to the worrying escalation of a new health problem. We had hoped that the letter would get her 'fast tracked' to x-ray but alas, that was not to be. We had a horrible long wait (ED was frantically busy and as fast as one patient got seen three more came in through the door) but they did their best to keep us informed. The delay was worth it - our friend was seen and thoroughly examined by an incredibly conscientious and kind physiotherapist who ran a number of tests after seeing her before sending her for the coveted x-rays. When the results were back the situation was carefully explained to us and they ensured that she would be all right before letting us all go home. Yes, it would have been nice not to have such a long wait - but that can't be helped, and all the staff were kind, patient, cheerful and professional. Everything that needed to be checked and done was; it was good joined-up work. Thank you all.

readBy.name: Royal United Hospital Bath NHS Trust

title: Wonderful GPs, rude receptionists
body:
My recent frustrating experience with Street Lane is similar to prior experiences, and I felt a review to summarise was warranted.

Once you have an appointment at this practice, things are great. The GPs at all levels of seniority are wonderful, thorough and have always provided outstanding care to myself and my young family. The GPs are a credit to their profession.

Unfortunately, the receptionists that must be dealt with before getting an appointment are a very mixed bag. 

Some receptionists at Street Lane are good listeners and deal with any queries efficently.

Other receptionists (both in person or on the phone) don't listen well, talking over me with the same scripted answers. Asking them to go off-stript is met with frustration and at times anger. Things are no better when corresponding electronically if these same members of staff pick up the case - I have had countless messages not read properly with poor responses, requiring me to clog up the phone line to try and resolve their misunderstanding.

It's hard to tell if it's a training issue or something else, but the receptionist experience is too often a deeply frustrating experience at Street Lane. 

From witnessing patients in front of me in the queue being talked over, and speaking to friends who are also Street Lane patients, the poor experience with receptionists is a widespread issue. 

I hope more can be done to improve listening and provide a consistant patient-focussed service from the whole reception team.

title: Efficient and effective responsive service
body:
I had a telephone consultation on 19/8/22 to discuss some word finding difficulties I'd been experiencing over the previous week or so.  I was not too concerned as I'd been experiencing word finding difficulties along with fatigue, since April 2022 when I had covid.
The GP took a careful history and recommended that I present to the Emergency Department at the RLH.
I did so, and was admitted that night.
I spent a total of 3 weeks on various wards.
Unfortunately I was diagnosed with a multi focal glioblastoma multiforme, a brain cancer which cannot be cured, only managed and has a limited life expectancy.
However, I believe that prompt action and skilled clinical decision making undoubtedly contributed to prompt intervention from other clinical services.
This has enabled intervention from primary services, leading to me having maximum chances within a terminal diagnosis.
During my inpatient admission I received a number of follow up telephone consultations from the practice, and found this reassuring, in a highly stressful situation.
I have subsequently experienced empathy and skill in a face to face consultation and in clinically evaluating and considering prescription requests and other administration.
Thank you to the whole team, but especially the GP trainee whom I had the telephone consultation with.
The whole practice team has been helpful every time I have contacted them regarding requests such as repeat prescriptions.

I appreciate that I am in a horrible situation but prompt investigation of the problem and the skill of neurosurgical, medical and neuro-oncology teams - has contributed to the best possible outcome for me, in an inevitably distressing situation.

title: Poor service
body: On phoning the practice for an appointment I was 28 in the  queue, after 20 minutes I was still 28 so hung up.  I then went on the Internet to 111, after answering all the relevant questions I was told to contact my GP.  I made a telephone call to the GP surgery at 11am and held on to talk to a care navigator, an hour later my call was picked up to be told they had no appointments, they were stretched and to call 111 after 6.30pm.  I decided to go to the Urgent Care centre and was given an appointment for this morning.  They said as I did not have a minor injury I needed to see my GP, they telephoned my GP surgery who said a GP would phone during the day. Approximately 1 hour later my GP surgery phoned to let me know I had an appointment, back, at the Urgent Care Centre this afternoon.  Thankfully I have now been given medication.  I feel I have been passed from pillow to post. Not impressed with the surgery but thankfully for the Urgent Care Centre.

author: MartyW
title: Fantastic stay
body:
I arrived 4 weeks ago. I was badly nervous and anxiety hitting the roof about coming in here but I knew I needed help with my drinking. I've struggled with alcohol for 18 years, never been sober in that time. Decided to give Asha a try because it helped my sister get over her drinking problem.  
  
The staff treated me really well, friendly and welcomed me. I felt taken care of and in a safe place. At the start I felt I was gonna be judged but it wasn't the case at all. The staff supported me and helped me to let my guard down. I've finished the program 4 weeks later and feel like a new man. Today as I write this, I am 24 days sober for the 1st time in as far as I can remember. This is a new beginning for me. I hope to rebuild the relationships with my family that my alcohol dependency destroyed.  
I would like to thank all the staff and everybody that has helped me through this journey. I couldn't have done it alone.  
Looking forward to better health, better life, doing more things with family and make up for the time I lost.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

title: Great experience
body: I visited a family member today 13/05/23 and  our outing was accompanied by a member of staff. We went for food, shopping and coffee. The staff member was absolutely excellent. What a wonderful woman. I was so apprehensive about the visit and she made it the best visit I've had. Chatty, bubbly and great fun. I can't rave enough about how lovely she was. Nice to see there's diamonds in there. Hope she gets the recognition she deserves. Thank you staff H

readBy.name: Bradford District Care NHS Foundation Trust

title: Very Poor Service
body: I fully appreciate how stretched the NHS is but there is no reason why staff cannot be polite and helpful. I witnessed all patients today being given the minimum information and almost being afraid to ask questions of the surly receptionist. There was zero warmth or empathy shown. No matter how bad a day staff might be having, they should remember there are a lot of human beings who need some help the other side of the counter. I waited three hours for my appointment and I‚Äôm ok with that, but it would have been better had someone said there would be a wait or at least looked as though they cared a little. The service was very very poor today.

author: Bhunabhoy
title: My experience at both my GP surgery and A&E
body:
I phoned my local surgery and expressed my concerns about a cat bite, which I thought might have become infected. My GP Dr Griffin saw me within two hours, and was concerned enough to refer me immediately to A&E at the RAH Hospital in Paisley. She gave me a letter to deliver on arrival, and spoke on the phone to an orthopaedic doctor, Dr Henderson, at the hospital to make him aware of my symptoms. She also phoned me en route to update me about this development.  
I was admitted swiftly to the Trauma Unit, where bloods were taken. The nursing staff who I engaged with could not have been friendlier, and they went to great lengths to explain how long the blood results would take, and that Dr Henderson would examine me in due course. This happened not long afterwards, and I was relieved to hear that treatment in the first instance would be oral antibiotics, and that an overnight stay to receive IV antibiotics was not deemed necessary. I had an x-ray taken, again extremely quickly, and I was discharged with prescribed medication a little over two hours after I had first spoken to my GP.  
All the health professionals I came in contact with yesterday really were tremendous ambassadors for the NHS. Everyone I spoke to was kind, empathetic and informative, and they reassured me when I found myself in a situation I hadn‚Äôt anticipated, which had raised my anxiety levels significantly. It was obvious to me that everyone, both at the surgery and at the hospital, is working extremely hard in very trying circumstances, but despite having so many demands placed upon them, everyone was totally focused on my welfare, and could not have been more helpful. I would like to express my gratitude for the level of service I received in both establishments yesterday, and to communicate to all the professionals I encountered that they have my utmost respect and admiration. Thank you for looking after me so well.

links.id: very well looked after and cared for

title: Good practice
body:
I'm waiting for next appointment
To sold out my problem with my knee
I was happy with my Doctor she explained to me everything so I will eait for my next appointment

title: Excellent staff
body:
I came here after been locked up for the night in a cell in Durham.  I have as here for 10 days.  Staff were absolutely amazing 
I was not from the area I was from Co Durham 
The rooms were lovely I had a hypomanic episode and was brought here n so pleased I was as no one knew me which made me more comfortable 
It been over a year now n I‚Äôd like thank you all for been so nice with me. Food was lovely on arrival I thought it was a private hospital 
Although I struggled with been there the staff were so nice with me n helped me get well and settle.  
Thank you 
Julie x from Co Durham.

readBy.name: Tees, Esk and Wear Valleys NHS Foundation Trust

title: Excellent treatment and care
body: I underwent total knee replacement surgery on two occasions in September 21 and Feb 23 and would like to say that on both occasions the treatment and care I received from the surgeon and nurses was  exemplary . My stayin hospital was for 2/3 days and on discharge was given adequate medication and an ice cuff  My wound was covered in a waterproof dressing and so was able to shower the day after the operation ,The clips were removed by a nurse at the doctor's surgery after 10 days. The followup physio and excercises ensured myknee attained the maximum bend. However not all NHS providers in Plymouth are as helpful . My neighbour had a total knee replacement on 5th May this year. She was discharged the day following the operation with medication but no ice cuff. Her wound has been glued and covered Una waterproof dressing but with instructions not to shower for 2weeks  When she rang her surgery for an appointment for the dressing to be changed in 10 daysan appointment was not available and she was told to go to A&E  . I feel very fortunate to have attended the Nuffield for my operations and fail to see why other providers are not as effective.

title: Great care
body: We had around an hours wait but the staff were lovely and the care given to my son was perfect, we all left reassured that he would have a speedy recovery. I am so glad this department is available as its local and easy to get to

readBy.name: South Tyneside and Sunderland NHS Foundation Trust

title: Stroke
body: My wife had a mini stroke when she arrived they told her she didn't stick her in a waiting room 7hrs told her there was nowhere to put her even though we saw a drunk man get a bed my wife needed to lie down a myth ago she had a stroke so she knew what her symptoms were they didn't even know she was missing till 10pm incompetence don't go to the lgi on a week day they treat u like poo

title: What a great hospital
body: Had a tendon transfer op with an overnight stay on London Irish Ward.  I had a bed next to a window with a great view and everything and everyone was so kind and helpful.  I have come back to the plaster theatre this week and I just want to say how brilliant everyone was there.    Thank you to all who have looked after me

author: Lucinda1
title: Education regarding alcohol
body:
I was referred to Asha via my keyworker in April 2023. I have found Asha and the services they have provided to me to be a real eye-opener emotionally and physically. The documentaries and education I received were brilliant. The staff made me feel at ease. They were very approachable and I felt confident to bring any problem I had to staff's attention.  
I'd like to mention that the healthcare was very good, I was checked twice a day and nurses were thorough in checking my blood pressure and stats. I felt so looked after and safe in this environment.  
I enjoyed the meditation sessions, yoga, relaxing music playing in the background of the ward very relaxing. I liked the daily walks and things people took for granted such as going to the local shop twice a week with staff. It was an excellent structured daily routine and the food was lovely. I was grateful to be in the unit with lovely fellow patients who I've really connected with and we shall remain friends after our stay.  
For anyone reading this and is referred to Asha, I hope I set your mind at ease. Before my admission I was scared and anxious, I didn't know what to expect. I was met on arrival by Tanya, Maria and Naomi (amazing people) I felt at ease straight away even though I was crying. They really made me feel safe and there was no judgement. I also want to say a big thank you to Jenna, Sean, Aidy and Malachy for their understanding and encouragement. It was really appreciated and all the student nurses, Caitlin and Jordon.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

links.id: very well looked after and safe

title: Excellent Service
body: I attendid the Imagining Department  for injections in the Ankle.  I felt immediate relief from pain, and to my surprise the pain in my lower back was more manageably. Thank you to Staff for making my appointment stressless. You are all extremely  kind, and work hard.

title: Quick and Efficient
body: Advised by 111 to go down, I was triaged, seen and on my way home within 45 minutes. Friendly and helpful staff too

readBy.name: South Tyneside and Sunderland NHS Foundation Trust

title: Perfect
body: My son at 6 weeks old was very poorly and needed urgent care, if it was for south tyneside hospital being as close ass it is I would of been worried of taking him to Sunderland hospital, we were seen quick and officiant got him diagnosed and then an ambulance to Sunderland where we spent 2 nights, but if it wasn't for the doctors and nurses at South tyneside I don't no what I would of done so I am forever thankful to them all and it needs to remain open for the the rest like mothers that can't get to Sunderland hospital unless they drive

readBy.name: South Tyneside and Sunderland NHS Foundation Trust

title: Pulmonary rehabilitation team
body: My mother and I have just recently attended the pulmonary rehabilitation on Wednesday and Friday  for the last 7 weeks my mother has improved and I will be continuing the exercises the course was excellent and the team were excellent 10 out 10 and thanks

readBy.name: The Newcastle upon Tyne Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Best Practice Personified
body:
Reported to the doctor with a worrying lesion on my arm.
Was referred to Ashford & St Peter's Hospitals.
Attended Clinic for photographs to be taken - within a week.
Saw Consultant Dermatologist at Ashford Hospital - a week later.
Had lesion removed (along with a second suspect growth on my back) - the next day.
Full documentation supplied.
Could not have wished for better treatment.

title: Not applicable
body: I received a telephone appointment so unable to comment on the practice. I felt that the the length of time I had to wait for the appointment to become available was not acceptable, especially as my conversation lasted approximately three and a half minutes.

title: Shocking experience
body: Chaotic, disorganised, shambolic, this was my recent experience in AE ambulatory care. First waiting room overcrowded and dirty, no one seemed to know what was going on, non existent communication from nursing staff who in the main ignored us patients whenever we tried politely to ask them anything. Triage staff nurse barely made eye contact when I was first called in, went straight to his computer to enter my details, no empathy at all, felt dehumanised. One very elderly lady adjacent to me was extremely upset as she‚Äôd no idea where her husband was. It took a volunteer lady to find out and take her to him, she‚Äôd been sitting there alone and anxious for hours not knowing where he was, nursing staff rushing past ignoring her. I appreciate it was busy but that doesn‚Äôt excuse the complete disregard and rudeness shown by most of the staff (apart from the doctors) I did after some hours see a doctor who told me to wait ‚Äòalong the corridor‚Äô whilst she wrote up her notes and my prescription which was urgent although pharmacy closed so I‚Äôd have to collect them on Monday! I waited and waited, nearly two hours later after repeated attempts to speak to staff in their meeting room a doctor came out with my prescription. (No idea where my doctor had gone) At one point a nurse rushed out of the staff room in tears, I know how she felt! No one seemed to be in charge of organising the staff in the department, it was absolute bedlam. I appreciate the NHS is under strain. I‚Äôm a former senior nurse and understand the pressures but a little humanity goes a long way. Doesn‚Äôt inspire confidence.

readBy.name: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust

author: Meandmesh
title: Care with compassion and empathy
body: My son was in recently and I have to say because I was unable to visit all the staff I spoke to by telephone were compassionate , professional and understanding given the circumstances . They absolutely deserve respect for the abuse and verbal aggression it seems like they sometimes have to endure, whilst continuing to deliver care with compassion and empathy. Thank you each and every one of you .

title: Amazing staff, shortage of support
body:
I was sent to A&E with chest pains from the walk in and the staff were lovely as I. Was moved to the heart monitoring area straight away.  You could see they were short staffed and I overheard one the nurses when asked if she had a break, ‚Äò who needs a break‚Äô she was amazing, organising, explaining to patients what was happening, providing advice while fixing monitoring machines.
Now I come to the part where hospital management should be ashamed, they were trying to monitor everyone who came in with only two mobile machines, until they could get them into the ECG rooms. One of the machines, should also take blood pressure, but it didn‚Äôt worküò±. The staff were trying to prioritise who could be monitored while trying to switch equipment that didn‚Äôt work. So I am making an appeal on behalf of the staff, please can you at the very least, provide them with the equipment to save lives. They are doing their very best in exceptionally difficult circumstances and it‚Äôs criminal not to support them with monitors that workü§Ø
I then witnessed an ambulance driver trying to help a young girl who took a turn for the worse  and he was so upset after, no one was there for him, I wanted to give him a big hug ü§ó he even came back to check on her. Anyone who says the staff don‚Äôt deserve reward for what they do need to sit in A&E for a while at the weekend 
For me, thank you to everyone who helped me , I only hope the equipment is provided soon to help you ü§ûüëèüëè

readBy.name: Blackpool Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Making the simple, unnecessarily complicated
body: Was required to attend triage for what should have been a simple blood pressure check and blood test at the request of community midwives (high risk pregnancy). Ultimately took over 7 hours. Not even an offer of some water during my entire stay and had to repeatedly provide my information and an explanation of why I was there. Priority treatment/care given to familiar patients. Lack of confidentiality around sensitive information. One midwife in particular had terrible bedside manner. Ended up breaking down to a very kind and sympathetic doctor; I was hungry, thirsty, utterly exhausted and just wanted to go home. Midwife's explanation was it was all because of "badgernotes" which, quite frankly, I watched the team obsess over with complete incompetence and at the cost of basic patient care. Not to mention the "security" guard who sat in patient/relative chairs on his phone the entire time, forcing other patients to sit on the floor- May as well have been paying me!

readBy.name: York and Scarborough Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Very good practice
body: Very good experience. Friendly smiling receptionist. Dr was helpful and informative only thing I can complain about is took a few weeks before I could get appointment. As the appointment was arranged by text it was a bit awkward as I was at work and couldn‚Äôt have my phone out, so when I received a text offering appointment for one hour later and I don‚Äôt work in Calne I couldn‚Äôt take appointment at such short notice. Then offered telephone appointment which I also had to decline. I was surprised to then be offered one the same day but later which I was pleased about as thought I would have to wait a few weeks again. So quite happy with the service considering the pressure on the n h s

title: Minor Injuries Great Service
body: Broken bone in foot.  Attended early in a Sunday morning. Dealt with quickly, professionally and reassuringly. Excellent team. Thanks

title: Fantastic Practice With a fantastic Doctor
body:
I very recently joined Deerness Park Medical Group and had to raise a routine appointment regarding a nasal issue, I submitted an E-consultation forum by their website which asks approx 20 questions and with the opportunity for an email copy which is always useful!

The doctor contacted me within approx 2-3 hours (I wish I could name him as he was fantastic!). Actually took the time to listen to me and came to a solid conclusion for medical treatment. He even went the extra steps and explained why this has happened, what happens next, and a review in X amount of time. 

Never been more happy moving to this doctors, fantastic service! you deserve all the praise :)

many thanks

title: Staff Just Incredible.
body: I just wanted to say how appreciative I am of staff in ward f7. The nurses, doctors, Healthcare Assistants, porters and anaesthetists all went above board to make sure I felt safe and comfortable after needing emergency abdominal surgery. I felt completely looked after by every person here and wanted to give my upmost thankfulness to everyone that helped me. nhs healthcare workers truly went above and beyond to make my stay here feel as stress free as possible, and always had someone to voice my concerns to if I felt alone. I can‚Äôt express how thankful I am for my care. Thank you nhs heroes. You truly are incredible.

title: Covid vaccine
body: Went for my COVID vaccine today. This surgery has it worked out very well for giving vaccines. No hanging about very helpful

title: Quite useless
body: I am disabled.  My doctor wanted a urine specimen to send to the laboratory.  She sent a dhu nurse who had the necessary container but who refused to deliver the specimen to the surgery which was the sole reason for sending the nurse to my home.  She seemed to think the task was demeaning.  I have not yet been able to get anyone to take a specimen to the surgery which is very close to my home.  Dhu people seem impractical and my doctor should have been warned that dhu employees do not do what she required.  They don‚Äôt do swabs, etc. either.

title: Amazing
body: I went in for my daughter who had a bad chest. They were amazing with her (she was 6 months at the time)

readBy.name: South Tyneside and Sunderland NHS Foundation Trust

title: Consistently good and caring
body: Had another appointment this week.  Face to face.  Not rushed at all, helpful and felt listened to.  The surgery was calm and everyone was happy to help.  I have a couple of follow up actions arising from the appointment and these will be easy to complete via the text message link sent.  Quick and simple.  Thank you River Surgery again.

title: A and E
body: I recently had an unexpected A and E visit resulting in me needing some surgery. I really can‚Äôt fault the care I received from A and E to the surgeons to the recovery ward. Every single interaction I had with staff made me felt cared for and confident I was getting the best treatment. A big thank you!

title: Availability of website
body: You say that in order to provide patients with a better service your website will be open from 8am to 9am Monday to Friday.  This is not  helping patients.  It is unacceptable for the website to be available for only 5 hours a week.  Many of us are unable to get access during your opening hours.

title: The most wonderful staff
body: I just want to say the biggest thank you to all of the staff in the delivery suite, theatres, recovery and Folkestone ward. You were all so amazing, from the second I arrived at the hospital for my induction of Labour. You were all so patient, kind, helpful and reassuring. I got a little stressed and fed up at some point but the midwives were there to support me at all times. The anaesthetists were so wonderful and thorough. You took me through everything you were going to do in detail, so I fully understood, which reassured me massively. The theatre staff who helped deliver my baby safely into the world. My wonderful midwife MS, you were truly amazing and loving and I‚Äôm so pleased I was gifted you for the arrival of my baby. The recovery staff and Folkestone ward staff - you were all so helpful and patient. I cant thank you all enough, you‚Äôre all truly amazing.

readBy.name: East Kent Hospitals University NHS Foundation Trust

author: Ritchie234
title: Care of a Loved One
body:
Ward 2 St. Andrews cared for a my Dad in his last weeks of life. They provided great care and support to my dad and my family. Nothing was too much effort and always had time to update us.  
They allowed me to carry out the care of my dad when we were into visit, as well as giving us time to spend with our dad, but discreetly being in the background when required.  
It was a calming area and I couldn‚Äôt have asked for a better place for my dad to spend his last days of life.  
Staff were very helpful and although I can‚Äôt remember them all, I would like to thank, Staff Nurses Alec, Susan, Rachael and Nicola.  
Thank you so much for allowing us the time to spend with my dad.

title: An exceptional GP Practice
body: One of my best decisions in life was to register with this GP Practice. The Surgery is situated in a very pleasant house building, and from the minute I entered the Reception area , I was struck by the calm environment. The Receptionist was extremely pleasant and helpful and respectful.  From the minute I entered the GP room I could feel the stress leaving my body.  He is beyond exceptional in his professional role.   He is a Senior Partner in the practice and he treated me in a very caring and kindly manner,  and removed all my anxieties and fears regarding my health issues immediately and talked to me in a very clear and simple manner regarding my ailments which allowed me to understand what the problem was, which turned out to be nothing to worry about.   A huge weight dropped off my mind and his manner of communicating and dealing with the situation was medicine in itself.   I left there feeling very humbled and grateful to have such an amazing GP and a lovely environment and I felt like a human being again instead of being a statistic in the Medical Profession.  I travelled outside my zone specifically to attend this surgery and to have my appointment dealt with by what I deem to be one of the best GPs in London. Not only did he allay my worries and concerns regarding my ailments which turned out to be trivial, he boosted my mental health well being and I returned home feeling very positive and ready to embrace the day.    Thank you GP and Receptionist.

title: Positive experience
body: I called 111 after my 2 year old had an urine infection.  They picked up within 5 minutes,  on call Dr called within the hour, my daughter was seen that morning at bracknell healthspace,  the lovely security guard helped me carry my double pram up the stairs and the Dr saw me on time and was friendly. The receptionist was friendly and showed me the way out using another lift. I feel lucky we have a local health centre. Although it was not busy and may not be a smooth service for wveryone,i feel lucky to have a local health centre and nhs.

title: Excellent practice
body:
Have been with Windrush since 1971, along with my late husband and three children. Have always been well treated, often beyond the call of duty, too many instances to mention.
They are coping as well as possible in the current circumstances.

title: Prompt and well organised.
body: I came to the medical centre to have my covid booster vaccine. I came in 20 minutes before my appointment. I was seen promptly at the reception desk and then guided and helped by the volunteers and then seen before my time by the doctor for my vaccine.  I was on the way home when it was my actual appointment time.

author: Andy234
title: Sacroiliac Joint Dysfunction (SI Joint Pain) outstanding treatment
body:
I live with chronic pain from Sacroiliac Joint Dysfunction (SI Joint Pain), and consequently I have to have CT guided injections into my SI joint 2 or 3 times a year to take the edge of the pain. I normally have this treatment at Glasgow's New Victoria Hospital, however my last procedure prior to today was given at Glasgow's Gartnavel Hospital and this procedure was delivered in a different, more rushed, manner which actually left me in pain and discomfort without receiving any targeted pain relief at all.  
It was with relief that when I received my appointment for today's procedure I noted it was back at the New Victoria Hospital.  
Today I arrived right on the dot and had only sat down when a cheery nurse came out and introduced herself and guided me to the changing rooms with some gowns and some instructions. A few minutes later the nurse took me to the CT room where the procedure would be done. After being introduced to the other 2 nurses on the team I discovered that the procedure would be carried out by *Doctor Lam who had carried out my previous procedures at this hospital.  
He explained everything he'd be doing very clearly, took plenty of time targeting with the CT machine to ensure that the injections got to where they were needed and gave me as long a period of relief as possible.  
Sometimes it's only when you get a really contrasting experience, in my case at Gartnavel Hospital, that you realise how excellent the service you get and how professional the staff are. In this instance I want to thank Dr. Lan for the very welcome pain relief, and also Paula, Lindy and Martine for making this procedure comfortable, respectful and cheery.  
The reason I sought out this site and wrote this, is that for one reason and another it's usually the negative experiences which gets all the bandwidth and the column inches. Not in any way to diminish the stories from these people, which must be told, I think it's especially important to highlight and raise up our NHS staff, nurses, doctors and orderlies, who work at the coal face and who continue to strive for positive outcomes and deliver, in my case any way relief, day after day after day.  
Thank you.  
*(? possibly spelt Lan)  
[Very happy with 'Staff skills']  
[Very happy with 'Staff attitude']

title: Midwife
body: I‚Äôm on my second pregnancy and I never felt any sympathy from her, never answered on time to my phone calls or messages. When I had my first pregnancy she didn‚Äôt even see me once, just on my second pregnancy and all very quickly, not too many questions, no communication. They make me appointments and no one is letting me know about it, no letters, no text messages, just sometimes‚Ä¶ after they call and just tell you that you have missed an appointment you had no idea about. I mentioned so many times I struggle with mental health and it is pretty hard to cope, but probably they are too tired to do their job anymore. If you can‚Äôt be a compassionate person, please don‚Äôt so it anymore. You have no idea of the impact it can have on people. For you might be a small thing, for others everything !!! It is exhausting. Luckily is my last pregnancy and I will change the surgery as well‚Ä¶

title: Excellent service
body:
I was having an operation at Weston General and got an infection. I phoned the surgery at 11.20, had a call back at 1450 and had antibiotics delivered to my door at 1710.  Result, I was able to have my operation the following week. As I said excellent service.
Faultless!

title: Fantastic practice
body: Broadwater medical centre staff and Doctors are amazing they are always so kind and caring and the service is great.

author: liontp43
title: I needed to have my Mirena coil removed to start HRT
body:
I had terrible difficulty getting to speak to someone. It took about 6 weeks.  It was hard to ring between 8.30 and 4pm as those are the hours I work. When I did try, the phone would ring & ring and not be answered. 

Having said that, when I eventually got through, the member of staff was really helpful and booked my appointment immediately. I was rather nervous when I came in for the procedure but the staff were really lovely and very professional. Thank you.

author: AimeeMx
title: Made sure we fully understood every step of the process
body:
I attended the queen Elizabeth university hospital to be induced with my first baby at 41 weeks pregnant, I was initially looked after during early labor in ward 48. I can't remember a lot of names from this ward but Pam and all the staff who looked after me were amazing making sure myself and my partner were comfortable and fully understood every step of the process. After 3 days I was taken to the labor ward where things took a turn and I had to have an emergency section, this was absolutely terrifying to me and I really worried about my whole pregnancy particularly how I would be post section and recovery.  
After our baby arrived we were moved to ward 50. From the minute I arrived in the ward still feeling strong effects from the spinal and unable to really look after my baby the midwife's, after care and even auxilliary staff were amazing in helping me so I could care for my baby while my husband had gone home to try get a sleep after a long night. I mainly had midwife Taylor look after my throughout stay who was great and reassured me so much ! but also a number of other midwife's. Nothing was too much and I've never been so well looked after! We ended up with a short stay at the intensive care unit which led us to stay in ward 50 for a total of 5 days while my baby received antibiotics for an infection and again amazing care from the nicu staff. The whole situation was exactly what I was desperate to avoid for having my baby but due to the staff , Taylor and Alison looking after us all it really was made so much easier and we couldn't be more grateful for everyone that we dealt with during our week in the hospital ! Thank you all so much.

author: Lollipop124
title: Breast Screening Appointment
body:
I attended the breast screening clinic in Nelson Mandela Place. This was my first mammogram and I was nervous. I was greeted at reception by a friendly face and directed to the waiting room.  
The radiographer who conducted the mammogram was very professional with a relaxing manner that put me at ease. Everything was explained to me and the whole experience was quick and painless.  
My appointment was late in the day and I‚Äôm sure there had been many people seen before me but it didn‚Äôt show. Well done and thank you.

author: Scipio
title: Exemplary health care from a true professional
body:
Very happy at level of support for my cardiac issues.  
[Unsure about 'Waiting time']  
[Unsure about 'Cleanliness']  
[Unsure about 'Finding your way']

author: phasekc43
title: Staff were friendly and put me at ease
body: I would just like to thank all the staff in the unit who looked after me during an endoscopy. They were all very friendly and put me at ease. Special mention to BJ, Marianne, Shona and Darling. It makes a big difference when you're nervous and people are kind.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: cubebx85
title: Very professional, courteous, respectful and compassionate
body:
Today I had a colonoscopy procedure performed at Chesterfield Royal Hospital. I was a little anxious and worried, more about what they'll find than of the procedure. Being of a rather embarrassing nature I found the staff, nurses and doctors to be very calming and welcoming. Extremely professional and really helped me settle down and relax. The reception staff were excellent. The nurse doing the pre checks (Gillian I think), was very good. Talked to me in a very calming and compassionate way, very reassuring and polite when talking about sensitive issues.  
I was taken to a room to change, everything was explained to me at every stage. I opted for gas and air instead of sedation.  
Another nurse, came and fetched me through to the operating room.  
They settled me on the bed and got me ready. The clinician who was performing the procedure talked to me and told me what was going to happen, that it could be very painful and the nurses will help me at any point.  
The procedure was painful and uncomfortable, I had a little gas and air and was OK.  
Afterwards, it was told what had been found and what was going to happen next. This was very good as it didn't leave me worrying about the results. The clinician was very plain and direct about what she had found, for which I found it extremely helpful.  
The whole experience was excellent. Very professional, courteous, respectful and compassionate all the way through. At no point was I left feeling alone or lost about the procedure. A real credit to Chesterfield Royal Hospital.  
Thankyou all for your hard work and professionalism throughout.

readBy.name: Chesterfield Royal Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

author: KS70
title: Ultrasound on thigh
body: Visited Forth Valley Hospital today for an ultrasound on a lump on my thigh.  After visiting GP had appt for ultrasound within 2 weeks. All staff were friendly, helpful and re-assuring. Excellent service again from our wonderful NHS Staff.

readBy.name: Office of Michelle Thomson, MSP for Falkirk East

author: equuleusps35
title: My first chemo for prostate and bone cancer
body:
It was my first chemo session which is rather stressful as you are nervous but from the moment I got there and was met by Kathy who took me through and got me settled in  
I then met Jamie and Kerrie who went through what was going to happen  
All the time I was there they looked after me even down to the lady who brought me lunch and coffee  
All in all it was I found less stressful than I thought thanks to all the staff

author: Helenannvx23
title: Did a great job on my knee surgery
body:
Attended Stracathro for surgery on left knee, already attended previously in 2021 for right knee replacement.  
The team at Stracathro are brilliant, made me feel at ease on the build up to go for surgery, from the care assistants to nurses to the physiotherapy team every single member of the team were fantastic and you were able to have a laugh with each of them as well which again helped each individual patient relax.  
Nothing was too much bother for each individual nurse, even though I was up every couple hours for bathroom, it didn't seem to bother the nurses they were more concerned I wasn't getting enough rest to recover from surgery, I stayed in Strathcathro for 3 days and my doctor was Dr Love who did great job on knee and kept checking in on how I was and pain levels were.

author: George234
title: All very good from start to finish, no complaints at all
body:
I had a colonoscopy at Grantham Hospital. On arrival was greeted by a nurse who asked personal questions first then was taken to the day ward and shown to my bed.  
Another nurse then came and put wrist bands on took my blood pressure , sugar. A temp and another put a Cannular into my arm .  
I was then taken to the theatre where the doctor was waiting asked if I wanted sedation which I refused so he ask me if it was alright to carry on I gave my consent and he started.  
About half way through I was feeling terrible pain so they gave me air and gas the reason for this was my bowl is twisted he carried on all the time talking calmly and so did the nurses in the end it was carried out and I was taken back to the ward . I was given to another nurse then who looked after me while I left all very good from start to finish, no complaints at all.  
Thank you all .

author: moonhj87
title: Efficient service
body: Wonderful staff and efficient service from the ophthalmology department today.

title: Best service, ever.
body:
After having several heart attacks, I was admitted onto AEU ward, really busy ward. The staff there, from the top to the bottom worked tirelessly from morning and throughout the night. 
I then had to stay on the ward until a bed could be found in Sunderland as I needed a stent fitted. I was there for a week, before being transferred to Sunderland Royal where I stayed for 10 days before being transferred to James Cook hospital as I needed a triple bypass. All three hospitals gave above and beyond care. I could not fault our NHS service. Had it not been for the Doctors and nurses at Southtyneside hospital, I would not be writing this as they saved my life. 
I will be forever grateful for those who did their part in this. Thank you

readBy.name: South Tyneside and Sunderland NHS Foundation Trust

title: Resourceful teamworking
body: Enquiry was handled efficiently. *Once through to the receptionist, she was quick to take important details about my symptoms, very briefly placed on hold, quickly signposted, prompt and appropriate treatment received. Great team, great work. Thank you very much for your speedy action under pressure.

title: Supportive service
body:
Was given a same day appointment to see a health professional.
No lengthy delay holding in queue.
Call back service in place and was contacted by surgery.
Physiotherapist was caring and attentive.-
